policy_name: NCAA Division I Initial Eligibility Standards
description: Academic requirements to compete as a freshman in Division I athletics
sliding_scale: GPA 2.3 requires SAT 900/ACT 68. GPA 3.55+ requires SAT 400/ACT 37. Higher GPA allows lower test scores.
notes: Students who don't meet standards can still enroll but cannot compete freshman year (academic redshirt)

description: Students who don't meet initial eligibility can practice but not compete freshman year
notes: Academic redshirt year counts toward 5-year eligibility clock

description: Student-athletes have 5 years to complete 4 seasons of competition
clock_starts: First day of full-time enrollment at any college
exceptions: Medical hardship waiver (season-ending injury before midpoint)

description: Allows student-athlete to regain year of eligibility if injured
requirements: Injury occurred before midpoint of season
Competed in less than 30% of team's competitions
approval_process: School submits waiver to NCAA. NCAA reviews medical documentation and competition records.
notes: If approved, injury year doesn't count toward 5-year clock

policy_name: Division I Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum number of scholarships allowed for FBS football programs
notes: Headcount sport means scholarships must be full rides, cannot be split

policy_name: Division I Men's Basketball Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum number of scholarships allowed for men's basketball

policy_name: Division I Women's Basketball Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum number of scholarships allowed for women's basketball

policy_name: Division I Men's Soccer Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum scholarship equivalencies for men's soccer (equivalency sport)
notes: Equivalency sport means 9.9 scholarships can be split among ~28 players. Most players get 25-50% scholarships.

policy_name: Division I Women's Soccer Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum scholarship equivalencies for women's soccer
Maximum scholarship equivalencies for baseball
notes: 11.7 scholarships for ~35 players means most get 25-40% scholarships

policy_name: Division I Men's Track & Field Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum scholarship equivalencies for men's track and field

policy_name: Division I Women's Track & Field Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum scholarship equivalencies for women's track and field

policy_name: Division I Men's Swimming & Diving Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum scholarship equivalencies for men's swimming and diving

policy_name: Division I Women's Swimming & Diving Scholarship Limits
description: Maximum scholarship equivalencies for women's swimming and diving
Maximum scholarship equivalencies for women's volleyball
Maximum scholarship equivalencies for women's gymnastics
Maximum scholarship equivalencies for tennis
notes: Same limit for men and women

description: NCAA policy allowing student-athletes to profit from their name, image, and likeness
prohibited_activities: Pay-for-play (school cannot pay athlete to play)
Recruiting inducements (cannot offer NIL to recruits)
notes: NIL earnings do NOT count toward scholarship limits. Athletes can receive full scholarship + unlimited NIL income.

description: Student-athletes can transfer once without sitting out a year
requirements: Must be in good academic standing
Must enter transfer portal during designated window
second_transfer_rule: Second transfer requires sitting out one year unless waiver granted

description: Student-athletes must complete 40% of degree requirements before 3rd year of competition
requirements: 40% of degree requirements completed before 3rd year
impact: Cannot change majors freely if behind on credits. Must stay on track for timely graduation.

description: Many schools allow student-athletes to register for classes before general student population
benefit: Ensures classes don't conflict with practice and competition schedules
typical_policy: Athletes register 1-2 weeks before general registration opens

description: Rules for combining athletic scholarships with academic merit scholarships
ncaa_rule: Athletic scholarship + institutional academic aid CANNOT exceed cost of attendance
exception: Academic scholarships from sources OTHER than the school can stack without limit
example: Full athletic scholarship ($70k) + external merit scholarship ($10k) = $80k total is ALLOWED. Full athletic scholarship ($70k) + school merit scholarship ($10k) = NOT ALLOWED if COA is $70k.

description: Rules for combining athletic scholarships with need-based financial aid
ncaa_rule: Athletic scholarship + need-based aid CAN exceed cost of attendance up to full need
pell_grant_stacking: Pell Grant can stack with athletic scholarship without limit
example: 50% athletic scholarship ($35k) + Pell Grant ($7,395) + institutional need-based aid ($20k) = $62,395 total is ALLOWED even if COA is $70k

description: NCAA allows schools to offer multi-year scholarship guarantees
can_be_reduced: Only for academic ineligibility, misconduct, or voluntary withdrawal from team
notes: If injured, scholarship is guaranteed for remaining years (school's discretion to renew beyond 4 years)

description: Policy on scholarship continuation after career-ending injury
ncaa_rule: School is NOT required to continue scholarship after career-ending injury
typical_practice: Most Power 5 schools continue scholarship until graduation
medical_scholarship: Some schools convert athletic scholarship to 'medical scholarship' (doesn't count toward team limit)

description: Entering professional draft impact on NCAA eligibility
football_nfl: Declaring for NFL draft ends NCAA eligibility immediately. Cannot return.
basketball_nba: Can declare for NBA draft, participate in combine, and withdraw by deadline to retain eligibility (if no agent signed)
baseball_mlb: Can be drafted and retain eligibility if don't sign contract

description: California state law allowing college athletes to profit from NIL
key_provisions: Schools cannot punish athletes for NIL activities
Athletes can earn unlimited NIL income

description: Texas state law allowing college athletes to profit from NIL
key_provisions: Schools must provide financial literacy education

description: Florida state law allowing college athletes to profit from NIL
Team-based metric measuring academic success of student-athletes
calculation: Each player earns 2 points per semester: 1 for remaining enrolled, 1 for being academically eligible

description: Division II has lower scholarship limits than Division I
Division III schools cannot offer athletic scholarships
philosophy: Division III emphasizes academics over athletics. Athletes receive same financial aid as non-athletes.

description: Limits on practice hours during season and off-season
required_off_day: One day off per week (no athletic activities)
